bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 27, 1946

div1.p: Hench reports on his family. He also doubts Lambert's story. He describes efforts to contact James Carroll's son, George. He also hopes to find some records from Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 27, 1946
div1.opener:
November 27, 1946
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street, North West
Washington 7, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
You are exceedingly prompt indeed. I just re-
turned yesterday morning after a delightful two and one-
half days with my boy at Mercersburg. He is doing very
nicely there, adjusting beautifully, and maturing. He
is on the honor roll, likes the school very much, and
seems quite happy. On my return I found your two letters
and the memoranda which I am delighted to have. May I
hasten to remind you again that I never took Lambert's
remarks seriously, except that I knew he was spreading
that information around and was receiving sympathetic
attention in certain quarters; and, therefore, it was only
proper that you should be permitted to see what he had
in mind and to answer it for the sake of the record. Your
answer is satisfactory and dignified. I forgot to tell
you that in the Arobives Building two or three years ago
I was able to find an old series of special orders relating
to men temporarily assigned to Camp Lazear and I have
microfilms of all of them.

Do you think that I should write to Doctor Brumby
and try to set him straight? He is probably a rank
sentimentalist who would not be particularly amenable to
reason. He has never written me. I am debating whether
or not I should let him alone and assume that his work
will come to nothing or whether I should politely correspond
with him and (gently) disagree with his viewpoint. I
could do this by sympathizing with the viewpoint of him-
self and Lambert but telling him frankly that he has mis-
interpreted the facts. I shall abide by your decision in
the matter.

Miss Schnurr and I had a very pleasant and
profitable evening with the Reeds. They both gave us a
General Jefferson R. Kean

lot of interesting information, some of which I did not
have before. General Truby thought that I should contact
Colonel La Garde who might be able to persuade Carroll
to co-operate. I missed Colonel La Garde at the Pentagon
Building but I had a nice telephone conversation with
him at his home. He has not seen Carroll since the
latter was a child and believes he has no particular in-
fluence with him but will give the matter further thought.
I got in touch with Mr. Reed who is the son-in-law of
Sergeant Tracy, who worked with Carroll. I had seen him
on a previous visit when he had been optimistic about being
able to get Carroll's co-operation. To his amazement and
disappointment Mr. Reed got the same response from Carroll
that I did. He hardly got in the front door and is inclined
to believe that the man is crazy.

On my return I found a nice letter from
Major Gilhus, with whom General Truby put me in contact,
and I am having an interesting correspondence with him.

I enjoyed very much meeting the Members of the
Board. On my way downstairs I asked Admiral Stitt two or
three questions which opened a flood of reminiscences and
he kept talking to me until almost two o'clock down in the
lobby of the bank. I think, however, that through him
I may find some old records of Doctor Carters. I hope,
indeed, that my little snapshots come out all right and
I will certainly send you a copy.

You state that you feel that you made no proper
arrangements for my entertainment. Dear General Kean,
how could you entertain me more than you did? You gave
me hours of your time--the most valuable thing you could
give me. It is so much more convenient for all concerned
when I visit Washington for me to go to a hotel. In that
way I can come and go to the numerous appointments that
I always seem to be making. You have never been anything
but extremely generous and kind.
Please give Mrs. Kean my kindest regards.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
